awd_titl_txt: Tuning Antiaromaticity and Diradical Properties in Diarenoindacenes, Diindenoacenes, and Related Quinoidal Scaffolds
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division is supporting the research of Professor Michael Haley of the University of Oregon who is synthesizing molecules known as indenoacenes and arenoindacenes. Professor Haley and his research group construct these compounds with systematic structural differences to answer fundamental questions about how these changes affect the electronic and material properties of these compounds. A key goal is to develop simple methods to construct these compounds in order to study their characteristics. Examination of the optical, electronic, and/or magnetic properties of these molecules then determines how they can be tuned and optimized for use in optoelectronic devices such as organic field effect transistors and organic photovoltaics. Professor Haley and his research group collaborate with material scientists, host visiting scientists from primarily undergraduate institutions for extended stays in their laboratory, and have continued substantial involvement of a diverse group of undergraduates in their research activities.

Non-benzene-based conjugated systems, such as indenofluorenes (IFs), have been recognized for their potential as organic semiconductors characterized by low energy valence shells and a small band gap. This project aims to create extended IF structures and IF derivatives with heterocyclic groups to better understand the singlet-triplet gap in these diradical systems and to compare to the original IF system.  The team also constructs novel asymmetric IF compounds to determine the effect of the loss of symmetry on fundamental properties. The molecules prepared in these studies present opportunities for practical applications in the areas of nanotechnology and low-cost electronics. This project also serves as an excellent training ground for graduate and undergraduate researchers with broad experiences in organic synthesis, computational chemistry, crystallography, and understanding the fundamental relationship between molecular structure and electronic properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the past 30+ years, research on polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) has seen a remarkable resurgence in the chemical literature as molecule preparation and classification have been made easier with the advent of modern laboratory synthetic methods and modern characterization tools and techniques. One key motivation to this resurgence lies within the unique optoelectronic properties that PAHs possess because of their inherently high levels of pi-electron conjugation and delocalization. These attributes make PAHs useful as organic semiconducting molecules for a variety of materials applications such as organic photovoltaics (OPVs), organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), and organic field-effect transistors (OFETs). While a majority of studies have focused on molecules called acenes and related derivatives, these molecules are susceptible to oxidative and photolytic degradation. Given that vexing problem, there is a pressing need for alternative, more stable, acene-like structures.

 

Nontraditional structures that incorporate five-membered cyclopentane rings (CP-PAHs) such as the fullerenes and related “bucky bowls” have undergone rapid growth as well. This NSF grant focused on the pentacyclic indenofluorene (IF) framework along with closely related structural derivatives, where two or more rings within the larger framework are five-membered rings. With NSF support, we have developed and/or adapted general methods for the construction of a wide variety of  fully conjugated, highly colored IF derivatives (see Figure) and have been exploring their materials properties. What makes the study of these unusual molecules rewarding is that, besides being challenging synthetic targets, IFs provide fundamental answers about structure, bonding, and reactivity in expanded, conjugated molecular structures. In addition, these molecules have the potential to act as planar, rigid, electron-accepting cores for the preparation of advanced materials with novel electronic properties.

 

Work on this NSF grant has led to several key findings regarding indenofluorenes and their quinoidal analogues: (1) by altering the fused aromatic rings in a systematic manner, we can rationally “tune” the energy levels and energy gaps of the molecules; (2) expanding the benzene core to either naphthalene or anthracene and then doing the same structural tuning of the outer rings permits us to rationally alter the diradical properties of the molecules; (3) fusing aromatic heterocycles to the aforementioned cores provides structures that are even more antiaromatic/more diradical than the molecules that serve as our benchmarks; and (4) rather than using computations to rationalize experimental results, we are now able to predict what new molecular structures we should synthesize in the lab. All of these findings permit researchers to tune molecule properties to those desired or deemed useful for organic electronic applications.

 

The broader impacts of this program have included industrial internships of graduate students at local and regional companies, the exchange of graduate students with those of several foreign collaborators, the hosting of extended stays of visiting scientists including professors from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), and continued substantial involvement of undergraduates in chemical research via programs that promote participation of underrepresented groups. The molecules developed in these studies present opportunities for practical applications, particularly in the area of nanotechnology and low-cost electronics. Moreover, this project has served as an excellent training ground for graduate and undergraduate researchers in fundamental and applied chemical synthesis. These studies have provided the researchers with broad experience in organic synthesis, computational chemistry,  and x-ray crystallography, thus allowing researchers to better understand the interplay between electronic structure and molecular architecture.


Last Modified: 03/15/2024
Modified by: Michael M Haley
